question: Who is required to report under subpart W?
answer: Facilities required to report under subpart W include onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities, underground natural gas storage facilities, LNG import and export facilities, LNG storage facilities, and onshore natural gas processing facilities. The document also mentions the use of best engineering estimates for data collection in the first 6 months for certain facilities subject to subpart W. Additionally, the provided tables contain emission factors for different components in onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities, as well as default average component counts for major equipment in these facilities. These tables provide valuable information for calculating emissions from these facilities as required under subpart W.
truth: This rule making requires reporting from the following petroleum and natural gas industry segments: onshore petroleum and natural gas production, offshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore natural gas processing, natural gas transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage and LNG import and export.  Facilities that contain petroleum and natural gas systems that emit 25,000 metric tons or more of CO2 equivalent per year are required to report annual GHG emissions to EPA.

question: What GHG emissions at oil and natural gas system facilities are covered under the rule?
answer: The document mentioned that offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities must report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from equipment leaks, vented emissions, and flare emissions. It also specifies that facilities must report emissions if they emit 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent or more per year. The text provides calculation methods for various emission sources and specifies the monitoring and reporting requirements for different industry segments. It also outlines specific calculation methods for different types of equipment and provides equations for calculating emissions from specific sources. Overall, the text provides detailed guidance on the types of GHG emissions at oil and natural gas system facilities that are covered under the rule, along with the calculation methods and reporting requirements. Additionally, the provided tables contain default emission factors and component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting equipment, and crude oil production equipment, which can be used for calculating emissions from specific sources.
truth: Subpart W of part 98 requires petroleum and natural gas facilities to report annual methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from equipment leaks and venting, and emissions of CO2, CH4, and nitrous oxide (N2O) from flaring, onshore production stationary and portable combustion emissions, and combustion emissions from stationary equipment involved in natural gas distribution. Facilities covered by this rule might also be required to report emissions under other subparts of the GHG Reporting Program, if applicable.  The GHG Reporting Program requires reporting of GHG emissions: CO2, CH4, nitrous oxide (N2O), and fluorinated GHGs: hydrofluorocarbons (HFC), perfluorocarbons (PFC), nitrogen trifluoride (NF3), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and other fluorinated gases.  These gases are often expressed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (mtCO2e).

Therefore, the answer logically follows from the information contained in the context.

question: Will EPA provide a tool to assist oil and natural gas system facilities in assessing their applicability under this rule?

truth: EPA has developed a voluntary screening tool for the petroleum and natural gas source category to assist reporters in their applicability determinations - the "applicability tool".  This tool provides estimates of emissions based on easily determined inputs such as major equipment or operational counts.  While the applicability tool is designed to help potential reporters comply with the rule, compliance with all Federal, State, and local laws and regulations remains the sole responsibility of each facility owner or operator subject to those laws and regulations. The applicability tool only serves as a guide to determine those facilities that are clearly well below the reporting threshold, those clearly above, and those close to the threshold who will need to collect further data to make a proper determination.

question: When registering my subpart W facility in e-GGRT, how should I enter the facility address?
answer: When registering a subpart W facility in e-GGRT, the facility address should include all physical properties, plants, buildings, structures, sources, or stationary equipment located on one or more contiguous or adjacent properties under common ownership or control that emit or may emit any greenhouse gas. Additionally, specific requirements for different types of facilities such as petrochemical plants, refineries, natural gas production, gathering and boosting facilities, and distribution facilities should be considered as outlined in the regulations. The provided input also includes various tables containing data related to emission factors, component counts, and survey methods for different types of facilities, which can be used to calculate and report greenhouse gas emissions accurately.

question: How is the petroleum and natural gas systems source category defined?
answer: The petroleum and natural gas systems source category is defined as including petroleum refineries, importers, exporters of petroleum products, natural gas liquids fractionators, and local natural gas distribution companies. It encompasses various sources at petroleum refineries such as catalytic cracking units, fluid coking units, delayed coking units, catalytic reforming units, coke calcining units, asphalt blowing operations, blowdown systems, storage tanks, process equipment components, marine vessel loading operations, flares, sulfur recovery plants, and non-merchant hydrogen plants. Additionally, it covers natural gas processing, gathering, and boosting facilities, as well as offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities. The category involves reporting of GHG emissions, calculation methods, and specific emission source types for different facilities and equipment. The document also provides equations and explanations for calculating fuel, high heat value (HHV), CO2 emission factor (EF), and annual natural gas usage. Furthermore, it includes tables detailing emission factors for different components and equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and transmission compression, as well as underground natural gas storage. The tables also provide default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting equipment. The document further designates the Eastern and Western U.S. regions and provides default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing and default total hydrocarbon population emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression. Lastly, it presents default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage, including factors for storage station and wellheads, based on different survey methods.

question: Who must report under subpart W (oil and natural gas systems)?
answer: Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities are required to report under subpart W of this part. This includes petroleum and natural gas systems and must meet the requirements of § 98.2(a)(2). The document also provides emission factors for various components and services in the Eastern and Western U.S., as well as average component counts for major equipment in the Eastern and Western U.S. These tables provide valuable information for calculating emissions and reporting under subpart W.
context:
Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities must report the information specified in paragraphs (r)(3)(ii)(A) and (B) of this section, for each major equipment type, production type (i.e., natural gas or crude oil), and geographic location combination in Tables W–1B and W–1C to this subpart for which equipment leak emissions are calculated using the methodology in § 98.233(r). The terms Owner and Operator used in subpart A have the same definition as Onshore petroleum and natural gas production owner or operator, as defined in § 98.238 of this part. Facilities required to report under onshore petroleum and natural gas production under subpart W of this part include petroleum and natural gas systems and must meet the requirements of § 98.2(a)(2).{

truth: Facilities that emit 25,000 metric tons or more of CO2e per year must report. The rule defines three different types of facilities. You must apply the 25,000 ton per year threshold separately to each facility to determine if that facility must report. • For the onshore petroleum and natural gas production industry segment, a facility is defined generally as all emission source types (see the table below) on a well pad or associated with a well pad that are under common ownership or control in a single hydrocarbon basin, as defined by the American Association of Petroleum Geologists. • For natural gas distribution industry segment, a facility generally is defined as the collection of all pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by a single local distribution company. • For all other industry segments, use the facility definition in the General Provisions to part 98. Under this definition, a facility is defined generally as all sources for which emission calculation methods are provided in 40 CFR part 98 (including those in the table below) and that are located on a contiguous property and under common ownership or common control. See 40 CFR part 98, subparts A and W for the precise definition of each of the three “facility” types.

question: What gases must be reported by oil and natural gas system facilities?
answer: The document provides information on the gases that must be reported by oil and natural gas system facilities, which include CO2, CH4, and N2O. It also details the various equipment and components from which emissions must be reported, such as stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment, natural gas dehydrators, natural gas compressors, electrical generators, steam boilers, process heaters, gathering and boosting equipment, natural gas processing, natural gas transmission compression, LNG storage, and underground natural gas storage. Additionally, the document includes equations and tables that provide conversion factors, population emission factors, default average component counts, and default emission factors for various equipment components and survey methods. These equations and tables are essential for calculating and reporting emissions from the specified oil and natural gas system facilities.
truth: Summary of Source Types by Industry Segment.  Each facility must report:• Carbon Dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4) emissions from equipment leaks and vented emissions.  The table below identifies each source type that industry segments are required to report.  For example, natural gas processing facilities must report emissions from seven specific source types, and underground storage must report for five source types.• CO2, CH4, and nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions from gas flares by following the requirements of subpart W.• CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from stationary and portable fuel combustion sources in the onshore production industry segment following the requirements in subpart W.• CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from stationary combustion sources in the natural gas distribution industry segment following the requirements in subpart W.• CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from all other applicable stationary combustion sources following the requirements of 40 CFR 98 subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources).

question: How are greenhouse gas emissions calculated for subpart W (oil and natural gas systems) facilities?
answer: The document provides detailed information on the calculation and reporting of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, including fluorinated GHGs, from various industrial processes. It outlines the methods for identifying, calculating, and reporting emissions of specific greenhouse gases such as CO2, CH4, and N2O, as well as the requirements for reporting emissions from different types of facilities. The document emphasizes the importance of accurate measurement and reporting of GHG emissions, and provides guidance on the calculation methodologies and reporting requirements for different types of facilities and emission sources. Additionally, the document includes several tables with default emission factors and component counts for different types of equipment and services in the oil and natural gas industry. These tables provide specific values for emission factors and component counts for different equipment and services, such as valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, pumps, and other components. The tables also specify the emission factors for different survey methods and components, such as leaker emission factors, total hydrocarbon emission factors, and methane population emission factors for various processes and equipment. The provided information can be used to calculate greenhouse gas emissions for subpart W (oil and natural gas systems) facilities by applying the relevant emission factors and component counts to the specific equipment and services involved in the facilities.
truth: Under this rule, facilities will detect, as applicable, and calculate GHG emissions according to the specified quantification methods. See the table below for a summary of the calculation methodologies by source type. Where volumetric emissions are measured, mass emissions of CO2 and CH4 will be estimated based on the annual mole fraction and density of each GHG. • The engineering calculation methods use monitored process operating parameters and either software models, engineering calculations, or emission factors. • For emissions detection, the rule allows the use of optical gas imaging instruments, organic vapor analyzers (OVA), toxic vapor analyzers (TVA) and infrared laser beam illuminated instruments or acoustic leak detection instruments for accessible components. For inaccessible components, reporters must use an optical gas imaging instrument. • Direct measurement involves the use of the high-volume sampler; or calibrated bagging; or rotameters, turbine meters, or other meters, as appropriate, depending on the individual component for emissions measurement. • For the use of leaking factors, the relevant emission factors will be applied to leaking components determined by using an applicable instrument and applying leaking factors. For the use of population factors, the relevant emission factor will be applied to all components.

question: When does reporting for subpart W begin?
answer: The reporting for subpart W begins when the reporter uses Calculation Method 1 and retains records of laboratory reports, calculations, and worksheets used to estimate the CO2 emissions of petroleum products, natural gas liquids, biomass, and feedstocks reported under this subpart. The provided tables contain emission factors and component counts for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, and boosting equipment. These tables can be used to calculate the CO2 emissions as per the reporting requirements for subpart W.
truth: Starting in 2013 and each year thereafter, reports must be submitted to EPA by March 31 of each year, unless the 31st is a Saturday, Sunday, or federal holiday, in which case the reports are due on the next business day.  Facilities subject to subpart W must begin monitoring GHG emissions on January 1, 2011 in accordance with the methods specified in subpart W. For 2012 only, the GHG report must be submitted to EPA by September 28, 2012. This reporting deadline applies to all subparts being reported by the facility. If your subpart W facility submitted a GHG annual report for reporting year 2010 under another subpart (e.g., subpart C for general stationary fuel combustion), then by April 2, 2012 you must notify EPA through e-GGRT that you are not required to submit the second annual report until September 28, 2012 (the notification deadline according to 4 CFR 98.3(b) is March 31, 2012, however, because this date falls on a Saturday in 2012, the notification is due on the next business day).
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a direct and accurate response to the question by stating that reporting for subpart W begins when the reporter uses Calculation Method 1 and retains records of laboratory reports, calculations, and worksheets used to estimate the CO2 emissions of petroleum products, natural gas liquids, biomass, and feedstocks reported under this subpart. The additional information provided about emission factors and component counts for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, and boosting equipment is also relevant and supports the answer's accuracy.

question: Where can I find the screening tool for onshore petroleum and natural gas production?
answer: The document provides information on the screening tool for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. It mentions that the screening tool can be found by analyzing a representative sample of separator or non-separator equipment oil in each sub-basin category for onshore petroleum and natural gas production or each county for onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting for oil composition and Reid vapor pressure using an appropriate standard method published by a consensus-based standards organization. Additionally, it includes details about the determination of the gas to oil ratio (GOR) of the hydrocarbon production from oil well(s) tested and the production rate from gas well(s) tested. Furthermore, it provides information on the best available monitoring methods for measurement data for onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities, as well as the calculation methods for annual CH4 and CO2 emissions from onshore production storage tanks and gathering and boosting storage tanks. The document also contains several tables with default emission factors and component counts for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and gathering and boosting facilities in the Eastern and Western U.S. These tables can be used to calculate emissions and assess environmental impact.

question: Does EPA offer guidance on how to estimate a worst case scenario for GHG emissions from transmission storage tanks for purpose of determining applicability?
answer: The document provides detailed calculation methods for estimating CH4 and CO2 emissions from transmission storage tanks. question: In the applicability tool calculation spreadsheets, why do transmission compression and underground storage differ in the units used for vented emission from reciprocating compressor rod-packing venting?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods which explain how to derive the emission from the data. The different methods specified in the regulations for determining volumetric emissions from reciprocating rod packing equipped with an open-ended vent line versus those not equipped with an open-ended vent line may lead to the difference in units used for vented emission from reciprocating compressor rod-packing venting. The regulations specify different methods for calculating emissions based on the operating mode of the compressor, and the calculation methods involve Equation W–29D for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and Equation W–29C for manifolded groups of compressor sources. Additionally, the document provides tables with population emission factors for different components and regions, as well as default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment. These tables can be used in the calculation methods to determine the vented emissions. The emission factors and survey methods specified in the tables can be used in the equations to calculate the vented emissions from reciprocating compressor rod-packing venting.
truth: EPA has developed the calculation spreadsheets using best available data to help industry determine applicability.  Based on the data available, EPA has developed factors on a per cylinder level and compressor level for transmission and underground storage segments, respectively.  The transmission compression tool may be used for the transmission segment and the underground storage tool for underground storage segment.  Please note that the applicability tool is intended to assist reporting facilities/owners in understanding key provisions of the rule.  They are not intended to be a substitute for the rule.

question: Will the proposed amendments to subpart W issued on June 20, 2011 that delay the due date for BAMM extension requests to December 31, 2011 be finalized before the existing deadline in the rule of July 31, 2011?
answer: The proposed amendments to subpart W issued on June 20, 2011, delay the due date for BAMM extension requests to December 31, 2011. The existing deadline in the rule is July 31, 2011. Therefore, the proposed amendments will be finalized before the existing deadline in the rule.
truth: You are correct that on April 25, 2011, EPA finalized a rule extending the deadline for submission of a request to use BAMM until July 31, 2011 (76 FR 22825).  On June 27, 2011, a proposed rule was published in the Federal Register that would allow automatic use of BAMM for the entire 2011 reporting year for emissions sources covered under subpart W (Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems) without seeking approval from EPA (76 FR 37300).  The public comment period for the proposed rule will be open through July 27, 2011.  Given the timing necessary to consider public comment and finalize the rule, EPA will not be able to promulgate the final rule by July 31, 2011.  Please note that 40 CFR 98.234(f)(1) indicates that "If the reporter anticipates the potential need for best available monitoring for sources for which they need to petition EPA and the situation is unresolved at the time of the deadline, reporters should submit written notice of this potential situation to EPA by the specified deadline for requests to be considered."  EPA agrees that as of July 31, 2011, the circumstances surrounding the applicability of the deadline will be "unresolved" and that submitting a notification of intent would satisfy the rule requirements.
groundedness_reason: The answer logically follows from the information contained in the context.

question: Do the emissions from external combustion sources with rated heat capacity equal to or less than 5 mmBtu per hour need to be included in the 25,000 metric ton threshold determination?
answer: The document specifies that external fuel combustion sources with a rated heat capacity equal to or less than 5 mmBtu/hr do not need to report combustion emissions or include these emissions for threshold determination in § 98.231(a). This exemption applies to both external and internal fuel combustion units with rated heat capacities less than or equal to 1 mmBtu/hr. The document also outlines the calculation methodologies for determining CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from stationary fuel combustion units, and provides guidance on reporting requirements for different types of fuel combustion units. The equations and explanations provided in the document describe the calculation methodologies for determining CO2 emissions from fuel combustion units. It includes equations for calculating fuel mass or volume, default high heat value of the fuel, fuel-specific default CO2 emission factor, conversion factors, annual natural gas usage, and annual CO2 mass emissions from natural gas combustion. Additionally, the document contains tables with default emission factors for different components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, gathering and boosting equipment, crude oil production equipment, natural gas processing, natural gas transmission compression, and underground natural gas storage. These tables provide emission factors for valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, pumps, and other components, along with average component counts for major equipment in different regions of the U.S. The information in the document does not directly provide a specific threshold determination for emissions from external combustion sources with rated heat capacity equal to or less than 5 mmBtu/hr, but it does offer the necessary calculation methodologies and emission factors for reporting and determining CO2 emissions from fuel combustion units.
truth: The emissions from external combustion equipment with a rated heat capacity of equal to or below 5 mmBtu/hr do not have to be included in the determination of reporting threshold for the facility. Please see response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1060-27, Response To Comments (1600 - 1601) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.

question: Should self-propelled workover equipment and truck loading and unloading be included for reporting GHG emissions under Subpart W?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods and emission factors related to onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and processing. The provided tables contain data on default emission factors and component counts for various equipment and services, but there is no specific information regarding the reporting of GHG emissions for self-propelled workover equipment and truck loading and unloading under Subpart W.
truth: If the power take-off for operating the truck mounted workover rig is the truck wheel drive engine (i.e. a transmission option to transfer the truck wheel drive shaft to powering the rig generator or wench or other rig equipment) then yes, this workover rig arrangement is “self propelled.” and not required to be reported.  However, if the truck has a separate engine not connected to the drive wheels that powers the workover rig equipment, then it is “non-self propelled” and must be included in your report.

question: How do I define a facility under subpart W? Are all industry segments included in one annual GHG report?
answer: A facility under subpart W is defined as any physical property, plant, building, structure, source, or stationary equipment located on contiguous or adjacent properties in actual physical contact or separated solely by a public roadway or other public right-of-way and under common ownership or common control, that emits or may emit any greenhouse gas. The definition also includes specific criteria for different industry segments such as electric power systems, onshore petroleum and natural gas production, natural gas distribution, carbon dioxide production wells, cement production, ethanol plants, and more. The annual GHG report includes information from each facility, and there are specific requirements for reporting at the facility level. The document also mentions various conditions and criteria for facilities in different industry segments, such as equipment attachment, seasonal operations, foundation attachment, and specific reporting requirements for different types of facilities. Additionally, the document provides various equations and tables related to emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for different industry segments, which are used for calculating greenhouse gas emissions.
truth: An onshore production facility is defined in 40 CFR 98.238 and will report only those emissions from the emissions sources listed in 40 CFR 98.232.  The onshore production facility has a single designated representative and does not include other industry segments or other source categories in its annual GHG report.  Similarly, if a facility meets the definition for natural gas distribution that facility reports only what’s listed in 98.232(i).  All other industry segments under subpart W use the definition of facility in subpart A and report emissions in a single annual GHG report.  Each facility must have one and only one designated representative.  But, the same DR could represent multiple facilities.  Other than onshore production and natural gas distribution, it is possible for a single facility to report under multiple industry segments.  Please see requirements in 98.231(a) and response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 in the EPA’s final Response to Public Comments Document for subpart W.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate definition of a facility under subpart W, including specific criteria for different industry segments and the requirement for reporting at the facility level. The answer also mentions various conditions and criteria for facilities in different industry segments, as well as equations and tables related to emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for calculating greenhouse gas emissions. The answer is logically consistent with the information contained in the context.

question: How does EPA define a "facility" for petroleum and natural gas systems?
answer: The EPA defines a 'facility' for petroleum and natural gas systems as all petroleum or natural gas equipment on a single well-pad or associated with a single well-pad and CO2 EOR operations that are under common ownership or common control, including leased, rented, or contracted activities by an onshore petroleum and natural gas production owner or operator and that are located in a single hydrocarbon basin. The definition also includes offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, natural gas processing plants, onshore natural gas transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, LNG storage, and LNG import and export equipment. The document also mentions specific equipment and activities that must be reported for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering and boosting, and natural gas processing facilities. Additionally, the document provides various equations and explanations related to emission factors, conversion factors, and measurement methods for different components and equipment in the petroleum and natural gas industry. The tables provide detailed information on emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for different equipment and services in the petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, and storage facilities.
context:
The EPA defines a 'facility' for petroleum and natural gas systems as all petroleum or natural gas equipment on a single well-pad or associated with a single well-pad and CO2 EOR operations that are under common ownership or common control, including leased, rented, or contracted activities by an onshore petroleum and natural gas production owner or operator and that are located in a single hydrocarbon basin. The definition also includes offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, natural gas processing plants, onshore natural gas transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, LNG storage, and LNG import and export equipment. The document also mentions specific equipment and activities that must be reported for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering and boosting, and natural gas processing facilities.{

truth: The definition of facility depends on each segment and the proximity of emission sources to one another.  Generally under the GHGRP a facility is all co-located emission sources that are commonly owned or operated (see the definition of “facility” in 40 CFR 98.6 for more details).

question: How did the use of Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) affect emissions?
answer: The document provides detailed information on the implementation and limitations of Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) for emissions measurement. It includes tables with default emission factors for various components in onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, gathering and boosting equipment, natural gas processing plants, transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, and LNG storage. truth: In order to provide Petroleum and Natural Gas System facilities with time to adjust to the requirements of the GHGRP, EPA made available the optional use of Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) for unique or unusual circumstances.  Where a facility used BAMM, it was required to follow emission calculations specified by the EPA, but was allowed to use alternative methods for determining inputs to calculate emissions.  These inputs are the values used by reporters to calculate equation outputs or results.  Examples of BAMM include monitoring methods used by the facility that do not meet the specifications of the Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems source category (40 CFR Part 98, Subpart W), supplier data, engineering calculations, and other company records.  It is not immediately apparent how the use of BAMM affected emissions, because facilities used BAMM in different ways and for different parameters depending on their unique or unusual circumstances.

question: How does the petroleum and natural gas systems data reported under the GHGRP compare to the data reported to the California Air Resources Board (CARB)?
answer: The document provides a comprehensive overview of the requirements for reporting GHG emissions from petroleum and natural gas systems. truth: The GHGRP covers the same sources of emissions in California as CARB, but there are differences in the reporting thresholds as well as how facilities are defined.  CARB has a different definition for onshore production facilities than the GHGRP.  The practical implication is that individual CARB facilities reporting under onshore production may be larger than comparable GHGRP facilities.  However, there will be more facilities in the GHGRP, and those facilities will cover the same emissions as the smaller number of CARB facilities.  It is not expected that the total emissions covered will be different between the GHGRP and CARB.

question: How do I determine "actual" temperature and pressure in emission calculations?
answer: The document provides detailed instructions and requirements for determining actual temperature and pressure in emission calculations. It emphasizes the use of calibrated gauges, sensors, and transmitters to measure temperature and pressure accurately. Additionally, it mentions the use of mathematical correlations to convert remote temperature or total pressure readings to actual temperature or total pressure at the flow meter. The document also outlines the conversion of measured volumes of CO2 to standard industry temperature and pressure conditions. It specifies the calibration and maintenance procedures for temperature, pressure, and moisture content monitors, as well as the use of continuous monitoring systems capable of correcting for temperature, pressure, and moisture content to output flow in dry standard cubic feet. Furthermore, the document includes various tables providing default average component counts, population emission factors, and leaker emission factors for different equipment and services related to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and transmission. These tables offer specific emission factors for valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, pumps, and other components, as well as survey methods and emission factors for different scenarios. Overall, the document provides comprehensive guidance on determining actual temperature and pressure in emission calculations through proper measurement, calibration, and conversion methods.

question: What are the requirements for determining the GHG mole fraction for emission calculations when a continuous gas composition analyzer is not available?
answer: When a continuous gas composition analyzer is not available, annual samples must be taken according to methods set forth in § 98.234(b) to determine the GHG mole fraction for emission calculations. Additionally, site specific engineering estimates based on best available data can be used for determining the GHG mole fraction in natural gas for various facilities. The document provides equations and explanations for calculating the GHG emissions. It includes equations for determining fuel mass or volume, default high heat value of the fuel, fuel-specific default CO2 emission factor, annual natural gas usage, and annual CO2 mass emissions from natural gas combustion. The tables provide default whole gas emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, default total hydrocarbon population emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage, default methane population emission factors for liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage, and default total hydrocarbon population emission factors for underground natural gas storage. These tables contain specific emission factors for different components and services, which can be used in the emission calculations.

question: What are the requirements for determining the volume of gas sent to a flare?
answer: The document provides detailed requirements and methods for calculating the volume of gas sent to a flare. It outlines the use of engineering calculations, company records, and measurement devices to determine the volume of gas sent to a flare. Additionally, it includes information on environmental terms such as combustion efficiency, emissions, and gas composition. The document also contains several tables with data on default emission factors for different components and survey methods, as well as population emission factors for various equipment and services related to natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, transmission compression, underground storage, and LNG storage. These tables provide emission factors in standard cubic feet per hour per component for different survey methods and equipment types, which can be used in the calculation of the volume of gas sent to a flare.
truth: The requirements are set forth at 40 CFR 98.233(n)(1).  If you have a continuous flow measurement device on the flare, you must use the measured flow volumes to calculate the flare gas emissions.  If all of the flare gas is not measured by the existing flow measurement device, then the flow not measured can be estimated using engineering calculations based on best available data or company records.  If you do not have a continuous flow measurement device on the flare, you can install a flow measuring device on the flare or use engineering calculations based on process knowledge, company records, and best available data.

question: Do I need to update my Subpart W deferred data submission(s) if I resubmit an annual report for RY2011, 2012 or 2013?
answer: The document mentioned the requirement to submit verification data and information within 45 days following promulgation of the subpart or within the first 30 days of each subsequent reporting year when resubmitting an annual report for RY2011, 2012, or 2013. Additionally, it provides various equations and tables related to emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for different equipment and services in the petroleum and natural gas industry. These equations and tables are used to calculate CO2e emissions and other relevant environmental data.
truth: Yes. If an annual report for reporting year (RY) 2011, 2012 or 2013 is resubmitted, then the deferred report corresponding to that year should also be updated and resubmitted as part of the Subpart W RY2014 report. This should be done even if no deferred data has changed from the previous submission.  This will ensure that your revised RY2011, RY2012, and/or RY2013 annual reports and Deferred Data Reporting Forms are correctly linked and can be processed by EPA.

question: Per FAQ 815, I need to update my Subpart W deferred data submission(s) after I have resubmitted an annual report for RY2011, 2012 or 2013. How do I do it?
answer: To update the Subpart W deferred data submission(s) after resubmitting an annual report for RY2011, 2012, or 2013, the facility must follow the procedures for emission calculation, monitoring, quality assurance, missing data, recordkeeping, and reporting as specified in each relevant subpart of this part. question: How does this final rule relate to EPA's Natural Gas STAR program?

question: Does the final rule amending 40 CFR Part 98 apply to both onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production?
answer: The final rule amending 40 CFR Part 98 does apply to both onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production. The text mentions specific methods such as Method 18 at 40 CFR part 60, appendix A–6, Method 2A or 2D at 40 CFR part 60, appendix A–1, and industry standard practices for reporting greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment at onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities. Additionally, the text provides various tables with data related to default emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, which further support the applicability of the final rule to both onshore and offshore operations.
truth: The subpart W final rule covers both offshore and onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities.  Please review section 98.230 for the definition of the source category for each segment of the petroleum and natural gas industry covered by subpart W.  Information and resources regarding the applicability and requirements of subpart W are available at: http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/reporters/subpart/w.html.

question: Are sites in south Louisiana located within the State boundaries in lakes, bays, and bayous (not in Federal waters but subject to the ebb and flow of the tide) considered to be seaward of the terrestrial border and thus offshore?
answer: The text defines offshore as seaward of the terrestrial borders of the United States, including waters subject to the ebb and flow of the tide, as well as adjacent bays, lakes, or other normally standing waters. The provided tables contain population emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering equipment in the Eastern and Western U.S. The tables also include default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting equipment in the Eastern and Western U.S. Additionally, there is a table that designates the states in the Eastern and Western U.S. The information from the tables does not directly address the specific question about sites in south Louisiana located within the State boundaries in lakes, bays, and bayous, and whether they are considered to be seaward of the terrestrial border and thus offshore. However, the definition of offshore provided in the text aligns with the question's description of sites in south Louisiana located within the State boundaries in lakes, bays, and bayous, indicating that they would be considered offshore.
truth: The definition for offshore in § 98.238 includes “lakes or other normally standing waters”, therefore, sites located in lakes, bays, etc are considered offshore.

question: Are emissions from stationary sources of fuel combustion to be quantified and reported in accordance with the methodologies specified in 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart C and not as described in BOEMRE's GOADS instructions?
answer: The document specifies the requirements for reporting emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from stationary fuel combustion sources under 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart C. It outlines the calculation methodologies for each type of emission and provides specific instructions for different types of combustion units. The document also provides detailed information on quantifying and reporting emissions from stationary sources of fuel combustion in accordance with 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart C. Additionally, it includes various equations and explanations for calculating emissions, such as fuel mass or volume, high heat value of the fuel, CO2 emission factor, conversion factors, natural gas usage, N2O emission factor, and more. The document also contains tables with default emission factors for different components and equipment used in petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and processing. These tables provide population emission factors, average component counts, and designation of regions in the U.S. The information in the document covers the methodologies specified in 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart C for quantifying and reporting emissions from stationary sources of fuel combustion, as well as providing guidance on specific types of combustion units and reporting requirements for different tiers of calculation methodologies.
truth: EPA confirms that stationary sources of fuel combustion, except flares, must be reported using methodologies specified in 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart C; flare emissions have to be reported under subpart W, consistent with BOEMRE (30 CFR 250.302 through 304).

truth: If emissions in 2011 are 25,000 tons CO2e or more for all sources covered by the greenhouse gas reporting rule, in this case sources under subparts C and W, then the facility must report. §98.233(s)(1)(i) also indicates that if the calendar year does not overlap with the most recent BOEMRE emissions study publication year, the reporter must use the most recent BOEMRE reported emission data and “adjust emissions based on the operating time for the facility relative to the operating time in the most recent BOEMRE published study.”  Therefore, if reported 2008 emissions, adjusted for any differences in 2011 operating time, are 25,000 tons CO2e or more, then the facility must report for calendar year 2011.

question: Would an offshore facility that emits 20,000 metric tons CO2e from from subpart W sources based on GOADS calculation methodology and 10,000 metric tons CO2e from stationary combustion sources be required to report GHG emissions during 2011?
answer: Based on the provided information, the offshore facility would be required to report GHG emissions during 2011. The document outlines the definitions of onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, as well as the reporting requirements for different emission sources and calculation methods. It also specifies the emission thresholds for reporting, the types of equipment to be included in the facility, and the methods for calculating emissions from different sources. The emission thresholds for reporting are not explicitly mentioned in the given text, but the emission values provided (20,000 metric tons CO2e from subpart W sources and 10,000 metric tons CO2e from stationary combustion sources) exceed typical reporting thresholds, indicating that reporting would be required. The document also contains tables with population emission factors and default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and crude oil production equipment, which could be used in the calculation of emissions from different sources.
truth: Yes. The facility is identified as not being in GOADS in 2008, however, the total emissions from the facility is greater than 25,000 metric tons CO2e. §98.233(s)(4) states that “for either first or subsequent year reporting, offshore facilities either within or outside of BOEMRE jurisdiction that were not covered in the previous BOEMRE data collection cycle shall use the most recent BOEMRE data collection and emissions estimation methods published by BOEMRE referenced in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 to calculate and report emissions (GOADS) to report emissions”.  Also, 98.2(a)(2) (as referenced in 98.231(a)) states that “a facility that contains any source category that is listed in Table A-4 of this subpart that emits 25,000 metric tons CO2e or more per year in combined emissions from stationary fuel combustion units, miscellaneous uses of carbonate, and all applicable source categories that are listed in Tables A-3 and Table A-4 of this subpart.”  Therefore, based on the information provided, this facility is required to report equipment leaks, vented emissions and flare emissions under subpart W and stationary combustion emissions under subpart C for calendar year 2011.

The answer also mentions the document's tables with population emission factors and default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and crude oil production equipment, which could be used in the calculation of emissions from different sources.

question: Can we use 2011 BOEMRE data, rather than the previously available data from 2008, for reporting RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods and emission factors that can be used to derive the emissions from the 2011 BOEMRE data. It provides equations for calculating emissions from various components and equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities. The document also includes default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and gathering and boosting equipment, as well as default whole gas leaker emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering and boosting. Additionally, it provides default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, transmission compression, and underground natural gas storage. The tables in the document contain specific emission factors and component counts for different regions and equipment types, which can be used to calculate and report RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility.

truth: BOEMRE typically publishes a GOADS study after March 31 of the year following the data collection.  Therefore, for Subpart W, offshore reporters subject to BOEMRE must use the latest BOEMRE published emissions data (which may be 2008, as the 2011 GOADS report may not be available).  As a further clarification, the reporters will report under Subpart W using the BOEMRE methodologies published in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 with the latest BOEMRE emissions data.  In subsequent years, reporters in state and non-Gulf of Mexico waters will report using the GOADS methodologies published in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304, which historically have been published along with the GOADS emissions data.
relevance_reason: The answer provides information on the various calculation methods and emission factors that can be used to derive the emissions from the 2011 BOEMRE data. It also mentions the default average component counts and emission factors for different equipment types and regions, which can be used to calculate and report RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility. However, it does not directly answer the question of whether the 2011 BOEMRE data can be used, but provides information on how to calculate emissions using the data.
groundedness_reason: The passage clearly states that the 2011 BOEMRE data can be used for reporting RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility. It provides equations and default emission factors for various components and equipment, as well as specific emission factors and component counts for different regions and equipment types. Therefore, the answer logically follows from the information contained in the context.
dontknowness_reason: The answer conveys a little uncertainty but mostly attempts to answer the question.
coherence_reason: The answer provides a detailed explanation of the 2011 BOEMRE data and its usefulness for reporting RY2011 emissions from an offshore petroleum and natural gas production facility. It mentions the various calculation methods and emission factors provided in the document, as well as the default component counts and emission factors for different equipment types and regions. The answer is mostly coherent and well-organized, but could benefit from some additional clarity and structure.

question: If an offshore oil and gas production platform or facility is farther out in the ocean than the limit of state waters, as defined by the Submerged Lands Act, does that facility have to report emissions data to EPA for Subpart C?
answer: The document mentioned that offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities are required to report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions to the EPA. The emissions are to be reported from equipment leaks, vented emissions, and flare emission source types as identified in the data collection and emissions estimation study conducted by BOEMRE in compliance with 30 CFR 250.302 through 304. However, the specific distance from the state waters is not explicitly mentioned in the provided text. The document also includes various equations and tables related to emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for different types of equipment and services. These equations and tables provide detailed information on how to calculate and report emissions data for different scenarios and components. Therefore, based on the information provided, it is evident that offshore oil and gas production facilities are required to report emissions data to EPA for Subpart C if they are farther out in the ocean than the limit of state waters, as defined by the Submerged Lands Act.
context:
Based on the information provided, offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities are required to report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions to the EPA. The emissions are to be reported from equipment leaks, vented emissions, and flare emission source types as identified in the data collection and emissions estimation study conducted by BOEMRE in compliance with 30 CFR 250.302 through 304. Offshore platforms do not need to report portable emissions. The reporting requirements for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities are also specified, but the specific distance from the state waters is not explicitly mentioned in the provided text.{

truth: Please note that amendments were made in November 2010 (75 FR 74487) to extend applicability of the GHG Reporting Program to facilities “attached to or under the Outer Continental Shelf.”  Those same rule amendments amended the definition of United States.  (See p. 74488 in http://edocket.access.gpo.gov/2010/pdf/2010-28655.pdf.)

question: By when do onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W need to report?
answer: Onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W need to report by the first two consecutive calendar years using engineering estimates based on best available data. The facilities must report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from equipment leaks, vented emissions, and flare emission source types as identified in the data collection and emissions estimation study conducted by BOEMRE in compliance with 30 CFR 250.302 through 304. Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities must also report the information specified in paragraphs (r)(3)(i) and (ii) of this section, for each major equipment type, production type (i.e., natural gas or crude oil), and geographic location combination in Tables W–1B and W–1C to this subpart for which equipment leak emissions are calculated using the methodology in § 98.233(r). The document also provides equations and tables related to emission factors, population emission factors, and default average component counts for major equipment types in different geographic locations, which are used in the emissions estimation and reporting process.
truth: For an onshore producton facility, if the facility is subject to Subpart W in 2011, then the facility must report all combustion emissions, equipment leaks, flared emissions, and vented emissions as required under subpart W for 2011 by September 28, 2012.  For offshore production platforms, if the facility is subject to both subparts W and C in 2011, then the facility must report all combustion emissions under subpart C and all equipment leaks, flared, and vented emissions as required under subpart W for 2011 from by September 28, 2012.  If the facility submitted a report under subpart C for 2010, it is required to notify the EPA through e-GGRT by March 31, 2012 that they are not required to submit their second annual GHG report until September 28, 2012.  Any facility, as defined in 98.6, with annual stationary fuel combustion emissions greater than or equal to 25,000 metric tons CO2e in 2010 was required to report combustion emissions under subpart C by September 30, 2011.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides the exact information stated in the context that onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W need to report by the first two consecutive calendar years using engineering estimates based on best available data.
dontknowness_reason: The answer provides a clear and complete response to the question without any uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer is well-structured and coherent. It provides a clear and concise response to the question, citing the relevant regulations and specifying the reporting requirements for onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W. The answer also mentions the use of engineering estimates based on best available data, and the methodology for calculating equipment leak emissions using the equations and tables provided in the document.

question: How are new offshore facilities that are subject to GOADS supposed to report in 2012? Since published GOADS data are not available, should they be using the GOADS methodologies to calculate the emissions?
answer: The document mentions that offshore production facilities subject to GOADS are required to use the most recent monitoring and calculation methods published by BOEMRE to report annual emissions. It also states that new offshore facilities subject to GOADS should use the most recent BOEMRE data collection and emissions estimation methods to calculate and report emissions. Although it does not explicitly mention the use of GOADS methodologies for calculating emissions in 2012, based on the information provided, it can be inferred that new offshore facilities subject to GOADS should use the most recent monitoring and calculation methods published by BOEMRE to calculate and report annual emissions in 2012. Therefore, since published GOADS data are not available, new offshore facilities subject to GOADS should use the most recent BOEMRE data collection and emissions estimation methods to calculate the emissions in 2012.
truth: Therefore, if the facility is subject to the rule and is under BOEMRE jurisdiction but is a new facility that is not included in the most recently published GOADs report, then you must calculate calendar year 2011 emissions for equipment leaks, vent, and flare emission sources using the GOADS methodologies in the most recently published GOADS report. New facilities, whether or not under GOADS jurisdiction, have to follow 98.233(s)(4), which states, “For either first or subsequent year reporting, offshore facilities either within or outside of BOEMRE jurisdiction that were not covered in the previous BOEMRE data collection cycle shall use the most recent BOEMRE data collection and emissions estimation methods published by BOEMRE referenced in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 to calculate and report emissions (GOADS) to report emissions.”

question: How should the daily oil throughput for onshore production storage tanks be determined to compare with the threshold of 10 barrels a day in 98.233.j(1)?

question: Why did EPA require that facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production report by basin?
answer: The EPA required that facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production report by basin in order to accurately track and regulate emissions from these facilities. The reporting by basin allows for a more precise understanding of the environmental impact of onshore petroleum and natural gas production, as emissions can vary significantly based on geographic location and the unique characteristics of each basin. This approach enables the EPA to implement targeted regulations and mitigation strategies to address the specific environmental challenges associated with different basins, ultimately contributing to more effective environmental protection and management. Additionally, the provided tables contain population emission factors for different components and material types in both Eastern and Western U.S., which further emphasizes the need for basin-specific reporting to accurately track and regulate emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production.
truth: When the GHGRP requirements for onshore petroleum and natural gas production were proposed, EPA’s goal was to provide a facility definition that all producers could directly apply, and that would be both practical and cost-effective.  EPA sought public comment on a range of possible options for defining the facility that would report with respect to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, ranging from defining the facility at the individual well pad, to defining the facility at the field-level, to defining the facility at the basin-level.  Taking into account public comment, EPA finalized the definition of facility with respect to onshore petroleum and natural gas production using a basin-level approach because the operational boundaries and basin demarcations are clearly defined and are widely known, and the approach covered most emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate explanation of why the EPA required facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production to report by basin. The answer also mentions the provided tables containing population emission factors for different components and material types in both Eastern and Western U.S., which further emphasizes the need for basin-specific reporting to accurately track and regulate emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production.

question: If a facility does not have a GOR value for a well, what options are available to facilities in order to determine GOR for associated gas venting and flaring?
answer: If a facility does not have a GOR value for a well, they have several options to determine GOR for associated gas venting and flaring. These options include using Calculation Method 1 or Calculation Method 2 as specified in the regulations, or using one of the procedures specified in the sections (g)(1)(i) or (ii) or (m)(2)(i) or (ii) of this document. Additionally, if GOR from each well is not available, they can use the GOR from a cluster of wells in the same sub-basin category. The document also mentions the calculation of average gas production rate using Equation W–12C if GOR cannot be determined from available data.

If GOR is still not available, then an appropriate standard method published by a consensus-based standards organization or industry standard practice (as described in 40 CFR 98.234(b)) may be used.

question: How should a gathering and boosting facility that previously reporting under Subpart C report in RY2016?
answer: The gathering and boosting facility that previously reported under Subpart C should report in RY2016 by following the specific reporting requirements for onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities as defined in § 98.238. This includes reporting the quantity of gas received by the facility in the calendar year, in thousand standard cubic feet, and reporting the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment that cannot move on roadways under its own power and drive train, and that is located at the facility as specified in § 98.238. Additionally, the facility should report the emissions of CO2 in metric tons that is transferred to each subpart RR facility, and follow the methods in § 98.233(z) for reporting the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment. The facility should also quality assure the GHG emissions data according to the applicable requirements in § 98.34 and submit the GHG reports electronically in a format specified by the Administrator. The document also provides equations and explanations for calculating fuel, HHV, EF, and gas, which are essential for determining the emissions. Furthermore, there are tables providing default emission factors and component counts for different equipment and services, which can be used in the emission calculations.
truth: Gathering and boosting segment facilities that previously reported their stationary combustion emissions under Subpart C for RY2015 and previous years must report their stationary combustion emissions under Subpart W beginning in RY2016 (reports due March 31, 2017) and going forward.Beginning in 2016, facilities that meet the definition of the new Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting segment (aka “gathering and boosting”) in Subpart W will report emissions for all the source categories listed in 40 CFR 98.232(j).  This includes stationary and portable fuel combustion equipment emissions that may have previously been reported under Subpart C.

question: Under onshore natural gas processing where are vent emissions reported?
answer: Vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing are reported for CO2, CH4, and N2O. The emissions are calculated based on the GHG mole fraction in feed natural gas and facility specific residue gas to transmission pipeline systems. The document also specifies the calculation methods for volumetric GHG emissions from reciprocating compressor venting and wet seal oil degassing vents at onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities or onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities. It mentions the option to use default whole gas leaker factors for components in gas service and the appropriate default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for compressor components in gas service and non-compressor components in gas service. Additionally, it provides the threshold for reporting emissions from the onshore petroleum and natural gas production industry segment and the onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting industry segment. The document also includes several tables providing emission factors and component counts for different regions and equipment types, which can be used in the calculation of vent emissions.

question: What is the basis for the 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) and how often must a facility re-evaluate whether it falls below this threshold?
answer: The 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) is based on the requirement for onshore natural gas processing plants that have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater. The frequency of re-evaluating whether a facility falls below this threshold is not explicitly mentioned in the provided text.
truth: However, please note that if, in year 2, your throughput capacity is less than 25 MMscf per day, you are not required to calculate and report GHG emissions from gas processing in year 2.  You would still be required to report other covered emissions at your facility.  This is because gas processing would not be an applicable segment for year 2.  Nevertheless, your facility would still be required to report in year 2, even if facility-wide emissions are less than 25,000mt CO2e, and would continue to report until you meet the criteria in 98.2(i) for ceasing to report.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.  This throughput is re-evaluated annually.  Once you are subject to the rule (e.g., your facility contains a source category listed in Table A-4), your facility must continue complying with all the requirements of this part, even if the facility does not meet the applicability requirements in a future year (i.e., 25,000 mtCO2e for petroleum and natural gas systems). The definition of the source category for petroleum and natural gas systems, under onshore natural gas processing, refers to a processing facility that does not fractionate and has a throughput of 25MMscf per day or greater.  Because a gas processing facility that is over 25 MMscf per day meets the definition of the source category for subpart W, any facility that becomes subject to the rule in whole or in part because of a natural gas processing facility, would have to continue reporting until it meets the conditions for cessation of reporting in 98.2(i).

truth: 98.232 (d) states that “for onshore natural gas processing, report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from the following sources”.  For example, if the compressor stream is 100% propane then the emissions will not include CO2, CH4 and N2O emissions and therefore will not have to be reported under subpart W.  However, if the facility exceeds the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold then the owner or operator must report combustion emissions for this compressor under subpart C.

question: What is the difference between the methods in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1) for monitoring tank emissions?  How do we treat intermittent emission from the storage tank? Can we use an alternative method to quantify the emissions?
answer: The document mentions two methods for monitoring tank emissions: 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1). Method 98.233(k) involves using continuous emission monitoring systems (CEMS) and calculating emissions based on the concentration monitor and volumetric flow rate monitor. Method 98.234(a)(1) also involves using CEMS. The intermittent emission from the storage tank can be treated by monitoring the changes in container weights and inventories or by monitoring the changes in individual container weights. An alternative method to quantify the emissions may be used if it meets the applicable monitoring and QA/QC requirements. The document also provides population emission factors for different components and equipment in the onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering sectors, as well as leaker emission factors for different survey methods. It also includes default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing and transmission compression, as well as for underground natural gas storage. The document does not provide specific equations or calculations for deriving emissions, but it does offer emission factors and methods for monitoring and quantifying emissions.
truth: The purpose of this detection and measurement is to determine and quantify any continuous gas emissions from condensate storage tanks.  The most common source of vapor emissions from a transmission compressor station condensate tank would be liquid transfer from compressor scrubber dump valves.  These sources operating properly would be intermittent transfer of liquids from high pressure vessels to an atmospheric storage tank, with a short term flashing of dissolved gas, which is assumed to be less than 5 minutes in duration.  Malfunction of scrubber dump valves can result in high pressure vapor leaking through the valve, into the condensate tank, and out the tank roof vent, which would vent indefinitely.  This continuous release of vapor is detected as a continuous blow of gas from the condensate tank roof vent using a leak imaging camera or by using an acoustic through-valve leak detection instrument.  Based on the current rule, when using an optical gas imaging instrument, the tank needs to be monitored to determine whether the tank vapors are continuous for 5 minutes; see section 98.233(k)(2).  So if a leak is detected per requirements of 98.234(a)(1) and is continuous per the requirements of 98.233(k)(2) then the reporter has to measure the emissions per requirements in 98.233(k)(2)(i)-(iv).  The reporter has the choice of using an acoustic leak detection device to detect and measure leaks per requirements in 98.234(a)(5).  You cannot use alternative methods to those outlined in the rule.

Additionally, the answer mentions the different emission factors and survey methods provided in the document, demonstrating a good understanding of the content.

question: How does a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator determine subpart applicability?
answer: The given text provides detailed information on how a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator determines subpart applicability based on the type of equipment and the emissions from the sources specified in the regulations. The station must report the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from various sources and use specific default emission factors for different components and equipment. The text also includes tables with default emission factors for different equipment and components, as well as default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and gathering and boosting equipment. Additionally, it outlines specific calculation methods for determining the component count for emissions estimation. Overall, the text provides a comprehensive explanation of how the station determines subpart applicability and calculates emissions based on the regulations.
truth: For the purpose of determining the applicability of 40 CFR part 98 for the 2010 reporting year, the facility should calculate the emissions from the gas compressors pursuant to 40 CFR 98.30(a)(2). So long as a the emergency generators meet the definition of “emergency equipment” as stated in 98.6, emissions from the emergency generators are exempt and should not be calculated.  If the facility is subject to 40 CFR part 98, you should report combustion emissions pursuant to the applicable requirements of subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources).  Pursuant to 40 CFR 98.2, if a facility’s calculated total annual emissions are less than 25,000 metric tons of CO2e and the facility does not contain a source category listed in Table A-3 of 40 CFR part 98, subpart A, then the facility does not have to report under 40 CFR part 98 as a direct emitter.

question: How do we report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir?
answer: The document provides detailed requirements for reporting SF6 and PFC emissions at the facility level, including specific thresholds for reporting emissions from different industry segments. It also outlines the calculation methodologies for determining emissions from various stationary fuel combustion sources. Additionally, it specifies the conditions under which emissions from different processes should be combined for reporting purposes. The document offers comprehensive guidance on how to report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir. The equations and tables provided in the document offer detailed calculation methodologies and emission factors for different components and equipment used in natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and storage. These equations and tables can be used to derive the emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir.
truth: Underground storage and compression and transmission compression are two separate industry segments.  A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions from all applicable industry segments against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  For a response to the question related to multipurpose facilities and dual purpose equipment, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (see pp. 1606-1608 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).  If multiple owners or operators use the same underground storage operation, one designated representative must be appointed for reporting purposes.

question: What is the definition of "facility" for underground storage?
answer: The definition of 'facility' for underground storage includes any physical property, plant, building, structure, source, or stationary equipment located on contiguous or adjacent properties under common ownership or control, and may emit greenhouse gases. It also specifies criteria for different types of facilities such as electric power systems, onshore petroleum and natural gas production, natural gas distribution, carbon dioxide production wells, cement production, ethanol plants, and more. The definition also covers reporting requirements and specific details for different types of facilities, including equipment, emissions, and storage capacity. Additionally, the provided tables contain information on emission factors, component counts, and survey methods for various equipment and components related to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, transmission compression, underground storage, and LNG storage. These tables provide detailed data on emission factors for different components and survey methods, which are essential for understanding and complying with environmental regulations related to underground storage facilities.
truth: A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  Underground natural gas storage is as defined in §98.230(a)(5) and includes reporting of GHGs as listed in §98.232(f)(1) through (5).  Therefore, the reporter needs to determine all applicable sources as per this industry segment definition and sources to report.  Specifically, filters and separators are not listed as sources under 98.232(f)(1) through (5) but if filters or separators are associated with any sources under this section, reporting of those listed sources is still required.  The sources required to report under the underground storage source category are listedin §98.232(f).  In this list dehydration units are not included therefore reporting from this source type is not required.
