question: Why do natural gas storage facilities not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment.
answer: The text mentions that underground natural gas storage facilities do not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment. This is because the default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for storage stations or storage wellheads in gas service are specified based on the survey methods outlined in § 98.234(a)(1) through (6) and Method 21 as specified in § 98.234(a)(7). The emission factors for various components such as valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, meters, and instruments are provided for both survey methods, but there is no differentiation between compressor and non-compressor components. Therefore, the emission factors for natural gas storage facilities are not specified separately for compressor and non-compressor components.

question: Does Subpart W require reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility or does reporting start only when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage?

truth: What constitutes a facility, how to determine the reporting threshold, and reporting of emissions from collocated and dual purpose equipment is as follows: 1) As a first step the reporter must determine the emissions from all equipment listed in 98.232(c) for onshore petroleum and production.  Per section 98.231(a) only sources listed in 98.232(c) need to be considered for threshold determination for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. 98.238 defines “facility” for the purposes of onshore petroleum and natural gas systems.  Per the requirements of 98.3 each “facility” must submit a GHG report for all source categories at that “facility”.  2) Note that while identifying onshore production emissions sources reporters have to determine whether the source is “on the well pad or associated with a well pad”.  The location of production wells within other facilities is inconsequential to this determination.  Sources on a well pad or associated with a well pad across the entire reporting basin have to be taken into consideration.  If your emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production are equal to or greater than 25,000mtCO2e, then onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities report as a separate facility and include all emissions sources listed in 98.232(c).  3) Except for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution, which have unique facility definitions, all other segments subject to subpart W are considered in the threshold determination for a single facility.  You would also include emissions from other source categories at your facility (e.g., stationary combustion).  If there are emissions sources that are dual purpose then the rule requires this piece of equipment to be reported under the majority use industry segment based on guidance provided in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (pp. 1606-1608).  4) For collocated industry segments, which cannot occur in the case of onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution due to the requirements in 98.231(a), EPA has provided guidance on emissions reporting in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14.  Based on the information provided, the facility cannot be reported as onshore production and natural gas processing combined (see point 1 above).  For all the other segments, the report should use guidance in points 2-3 above to determine the segment under which the facility should be categorized.

question: Please explain how many leak detection surveys must be conducted a calendar year?  Must a facility indicate in advance how many surveys will be conducted in the year?
answer: The document specifies that at least one leak detection survey must be conducted in a calendar year. If multiple complete leak detection surveys are conducted in a calendar year, the results from each survey must be used when calculating emissions. Additionally, natural gas distribution facilities have the option to conduct equipment leak surveys across a multiple-year cycle, not exceeding a five-year period, to cover all above-grade transmission-distribution transfer stations. The number of surveys to be conducted in a year is not explicitly specified, but it is clear that at least one survey is required, and multiple surveys can be conducted if needed. Facilities do not need to indicate in advance how many surveys will be conducted in the year.
truth: For natural gas distribution, a facility, which is the collection of all distribution pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by an LDC, is required to do at least one facility wide leak detection survey per calendar year and has the option to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys; if the facility selects this option, the additional facility-wide survey(s) must be completed during the same calendar year in order to account for fixing one or more leaks in the annual GHG report.  If the facility chooses to fix one or more leaks and conduct another survey to determine that the component is not leaking, it must conduct a facility wide leak detection survey in order to account for fixing the leak(s) in the annual GHG report.  As leaks are random in nature and while some leaks are fixed others are likely to occur.  Therefore, a comprehensive survey is the only statistically relevant manner by which to establish facility-wide leak emissions rates and account for leaks repaired.  Please see the response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1014-9 (Response to Comments, pp. 1281-1282, http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf) for further details.  It is very important to note that the requirement to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys should a company wish to account for fixing a leak does not preclude in any way a company from repairing a leak.  If a company chooses to conduct only one facility-wide leak detection survey in a calendar year but finds a leak during the survey, the company can and is encouraged to fix the leak.  The leak detected though, as noted above, must be reported as a leaker for the entire calendar year should the company choose not to conduct a second survey.

question: What happens if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components?  Could EPA provide a sunset provision so that annual leak surveys would no longer be required?
answer: The document outlines the requirements for conducting leak detection surveys at natural gas distribution facilities, including the frequency of surveys, reporting methods, and calculation of equipment leak emissions. truth: As noted in the preamble, the purpose of this provision was to reduce burden for reporters, including the option to better align survey frequencies between the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program and Department of Transportation regulations.  The statement in the preamble regarding a “minimum of 20 percent of their total number of stations being leak surveyed annually” was considered for cases where a facility chose a period of less than 5 years. We also recognize that there is a related comment and response in, “Mandatory Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule: EPA's Response to Public Comments: “2011 Technical Revisions to the Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems Category of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule” (see DCN: EPA-HQ-OAR-2011-0512-0030) where EPA may also appear to reject the 10%-10%-40%-20%-20% approach outlined above.  However, EPA understood the commenter’s recommendation as to be suggesting measurement of 10% of stations per year, over a ten year period. EPA’s objection to the comment to monitor 10% of stations per year would have been inconsistent with a five-year cycle.  Yes.   According to 98.233(q)(8)(i), “Natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct leak detection at T-D transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period to cover all T-D transfer stations.  If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, then the number of T-D transfer stations monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle without monitoring the same station twice during the multiple year survey.”  EPA confirms that an approach of conducting monitoring at 10% of the facilities in each of the first two years, followed by 40%, 20% and 20% in years three, four and five would be consistent with the rule language that the number of stations monitored be “approximately equal” over the number of years surveyed.

question: What types of instruments are permissible for use in detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W?
answer: The document specifies the permissible instruments for detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W. These instruments include acoustic leak detection devices, infrared laser beam illuminated instruments, optical gas imaging instruments, and high volume samplers. It also mentions the use of manufacturer's calculation methods for quantifying through-valve leakage when using the acoustic leak detection device. Additionally, it outlines the use of Method 21 for monitoring equipment leaks, with a specified instrument reading of 10,000 ppm or greater indicating a leak. truth: For conducting leak detection required by subpart W, reporters have the option to use optical gas imaging instruments, infrared laser beam illuminated instruments, or acoustic leak detection devices as outlined in 40 CFR 98.234(a).  In addition, reporters may use other instruments, however those instruments must comply with the provisions as stated in 40 CFR 98.234(a)(2).

question: Do acid gas removal units which are used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units?

truth: The definition of acid gas removal unit in §98.238 states, “process unit that separates hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators.”  Acid gas removal units processing a liquid stream do not meet this definition, and reporters do not need to report emissions from these units.

truth: With regards to acid gas injection wells and subparts PP and UU, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response to Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.  EPA requires reporters to calculate emissions from AGR units and then adjust them downwards by the amount transferred outside of the facility.  Therefore, if 100% of the CO2 recovered from an AGR unit is transferred outside of the facility, then CO2 emissions from the AGR unit must be calculated prior to determining the amount being transferred outside the facility.  Note that §98.236(c)(3) requires separate reporting of both the AGR emissions and emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility, even if the values are the same.

truth: Reporters performing on-site injection of acid gas may not adjust emissions downward. §98.233(d)(11) clearly states that you may only adjust emissions estimates downwards for emissions recovered and transferred OUTSIDE the facility.  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response To Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate explanation of the information provided in the context. It correctly identifies the requirement to report the annual quantity of CO2 that was recovered and transferred outside the facility under subpart PP of this part, as specified in § 98.233(d)(11), and confirms that facilities performing on-site acid gas injection can estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in this section. The answer also mentions the different calculation methods specified in § 98.233(d)(10) and (11), and provides additional information on the various factors and conversion methods related to emissions, including emission factors, concentration, flow rate, molecular weight, mass of emitted gases, and more. The answer also correctly identifies the presence of tables with default emission factors for different components and equipment used in natural gas production and processing, which further supports the accuracy of the answer.
dontknowness_reason: The answer provides a clear and direct response to the question without any uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer is mostly coherent as it provides detailed information on the calculation of emissions for CO2 from acid gas removal vents, including various calculation methods and the requirement to report the annual quantity of CO2 that was recovered and transferred outside the facility under subpart PP of this part, as specified in § 98.233(d)(11). The answer also mentions the injection of carbon dioxide for enhanced oil and natural gas recovery and provides additional information on default whole gas emission factors, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, and more.

question: For AGR vents is the use of a meter to measure flow rates required?
answer: The document provides information on the calculation methods for emissions from AGR vents, including the use of a meter to measure flow rates. It also mentions the use of continuous gas analyzers or quarterly gas samples if a continuous gas analyzer is not available. The document also defines AGR vents as including processes such as amine, membrane, molecular sieve, or other absorbents and adsorbents, and specifies that emissions for CO2 only (not CH4) should be calculated. Therefore, the use of a meter to measure flow rates is required for calculating emissions from AGR vents.
truth: The rule requires the use of a meter if one is in place.  If a continuous flow meter is not already in place, then reporters have the choice of installing a continuous flow meter or alternatively using an engineering calculation to estimate the flow rate; please see §98.233(d)(5).
groundedness_reason: The document clearly states that the use of a meter to measure flow rates is required for calculating emissions from AGR vents.
dontknowness_reason: The answer provides a clear and direct response to the question without any uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer provides a clear and concise explanation that the use of a meter to measure flow rates is required for calculating emissions from AGR vents. The sentences fit together well and sound natural as a whole, indicating perfect coherency.

question: For which units of measure are we required to calculate and report emissions using Equation W-3? May we use a flow meter to calculate annual emission CO2?
answer: The document mentions the requirement to calculate and report annual CO2 emissions using specific equations and methodologies, such as Equation C3, C4, C5, X–1, X–3, X–4, EE–1, EE–2, and others. However, it does not explicitly mention the use of Equation W-3 for the calculation and reporting of emissions. The document also specifies the use of flow or volume measurement systems to calculate emissions at standard conditions, but it does not explicitly mention the use of a flow meter to calculate annual CO2 emissions. The provided tables contain default whole gas emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, average component counts for major crude oil production equipment, designation of Eastern and Western U.S., default whole gas leaker emission factors, default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing plants, default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, default total hydrocarbon population emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, and default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage. These tables provide emission factors and component counts for different equipment and facilities, which can be used in emissions calculations. However, specific information related to Equation W-3 and the use of a flow meter for calculating annual CO2 emissions is not explicitly mentioned in the provided text.
truth: The units of measure for emissions calculated in Equation W-3 are in cubic feet per year. However, §98.233(d)(10) requires that the volumetric emissions of equation W-3 be converted into mass emissions using §98.233(v)’s methods.  You must report emissions in metric tons of CO2e to meet the reporting requirements in §98.236(c)(3)(v).  If reporters use the methodology set forth in §98.233(d)(2), then a vent flow meter must be used to determine the total annual volume of vent gas flowing out of the AGR unit.

question: For blowdown vent stacks does the 98.233.i reference to containers less than 50 cubic feet total physical volume refer to a gas volume or a physical container volume?
answer: The text mentions that equipment with a unique physical volume of less than 50 cubic feet are not subject to the requirements in paragraphs (i)(2) through (4) of this section. This indicates that the reference to containers less than 50 cubic feet total physical volume refers to the physical container volume, not the gas volume.
truth: The unique physical volume between isolation valves should be considered against the 50 cubic feet threshold for blowdown vent stacks.  As stated in 40 CRF § 98.233(i)(2), unique physical volumes smaller than 50 cubic feet are exempt from reporting under § 98.233(i).  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1018-27 in Response to Comments (pages 1464-1465) (http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).
dontknowness_reason: The answer provides a clear and confident response to the question without any uncertainty.

question: May average blowdown volumes be used for industry segments (processing, transmission, and LNG imports-exports) where reporting of this emission source is required?
answer: The document provides detailed guidance on the measurement and calculation of emissions from blowdown vent stacks, including the determination of annual CH4 and CO2 volumetric and mass emissions, as well as the calculation of total annual CH4 and CO2 emissions for each equipment or event type. It also outlines the conditions under which the method for determining emissions from blowdown vent stacks using a flow meter may be used. The document specifies various methods for determining volumetric flow at standard conditions from the blowdown vent, such as calibrated bagging, high volume sampler, and temporary meter. Additionally, it includes default average component counts and population emission factors for different equipment types and material types in the Eastern and Western U.S. The document also provides default methane leaker emission factors for LNG import and export equipment, as well as methane population emission factors for LNG import and export equipment. truth: Pursuant to a May 2013 final rule, Subpart W BAMM requests are due by June 30 of the year prior to the year in which reports are due (the “reporting year”) and for which BAMM is sought.  As June 30, 2013 falls on a weekend, BAMM requests for the 2014 reporting year are due by July 1, 2013.  The totality of the circumstances related to conducting isolation valve measurement on compressors in shutdown depressurized mode if fully explained in a proper Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) request may be considered by EPA to constitute unique or unusual circumstances justifying the use of BAMM.

truth: Facilities approved to use BAMM are still required to use the calculation methodologies and equations in § 98.233, and must comply with the reporting requirements in § 98.236.  The totality of the circumstances related to conducting measurement on compressors vents routed to a common manifold, if fully explained in a proper Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) request, may be considered by EPA to constitute unique or unusual circumstances justifying the use of BAMM. Pursuant to a May 2013 final rule, Subpart W BAMM requests are due by June 30 of the year prior to the year in which reports are due (the “reporting year”) and for which BAMM is sought. As June 30, 2013 falls on a weekend, BAMM requests for the 2014 reporting year are due by July 1, 2013.

It outlines the calculation methodologies, equations, and time periods during which BAMM can be utilized. However, it provides detailed information about the use of best available monitoring methods (BAMM) for various parameters in environmental regulations and includes various tables with data such as default whole gas emission factors, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, designation of Eastern and Western U.S., default whole gas leaker emission factors, default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, default total hydrocarbon population emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, and default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage. This information can be used to understand the regulatory framework and emission calculation methods for environmental compliance.

question: Will EPA approve the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) relating to the measurement of compressor vents routed to flare?
answer: The document provides detailed information about the calculation methodologies and equations to be used for various environmental parameters, including emissions from different components in the petroleum and natural gas industry. However, there is no specific mention of Subpart W or the measurement of compressor vents routed to flare in the provided text. The document includes tables with default emission factors for different components and equipment in the onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, as well as population emission factors for various services. It also provides average component counts for major equipment and designations of Eastern and Western U.S. states. The equations provided in the text define various emission factors, conversion factors, and calculation methodologies for different environmental parameters, but they do not directly address the specific use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) for the measurement of compressor vents routed to flare as mentioned in the question.
context:
The document contains information about the use of best available monitoring methods (BAMM) for various parameters, including fuel use and feedstock rates, when it is not reasonably feasible to meet monitoring and QA/QC requirements of the subpart. It outlines the calculation methodologies and equations to be used, as well as the time periods during which BAMM can be utilized. It also specifies the approval criteria and requests for extension of the use of BAMM. question: Emissions from flares are specifically excluded under 98.232(e) but methods for these emissions are provided in 98.233. Can you clarify which section of the rule is the correct guiding action?
answer: The document clearly states that emissions from flares are specifically excluded under § 98.232(e) but provides methods for calculating these emissions under § 98.233. Therefore, the correct guiding action for addressing emissions from flares is provided in § 98.233. Additionally, the document provides detailed information about the calculation and reporting of CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from flare stack emissions, including specific equations and methods outlined in § 98.233.
truth: Under §98.232(e), emissions from flare stacks are not required to be reported as a separate emission source for onshore natural gas transmission compression facilities.  However, this does not exclude the reporting of flared emissions from the other emission sources listed in §98.232(e) if they are routed to a flare.  The flare source type in §98.233(n) covers only emissions that are not reported in association with any of the other source types in §98.233; see §98.233(n)(10).  For example, if transmission storage tank emissions are going to a flare, then the rule requires the adjustment of transmission storage tank emissions sent to flare per §98.233(k)(4).  The flared transmission storage tank emissions, however, have to be reported as transmission storage tank emissions under §98.236(c)(9).
groundedness_reason: The answer follows logically from the information contained in the context. question: Does a simple open pipe with no flare tip count as a flare under 98.233 (n ) in Subpart W?

question: Under Subpart W, under both the onshore production and gas processing source categories, are we required to report emissions from all flares at the gas processing facility or on or associated with a well pad, including emergency flares?
answer: Under Subpart W, under both the onshore production and gas processing source categories, facilities are required to report the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from stationary fuel combustion sources following the methods in § 98.233(z). The term 'flare' is defined as a combustion device, whether at ground level or elevated, that uses an open or closed flame to combust waste gases without energy recovery. Facilities are also required to use best engineering estimates for any data related to newly acquired sources that cannot reasonably be measured or obtained according to the requirements of this subpart for the first 6 months of required data collection. Additionally, facilities must use the appropriate default whole gas leaker factors for components in gas service listed in Table W–1E and the appropriate default total hydrocarbon population emission factors for storage wellheads in gas service listed in Table W–4B to this subpart. The provided tables contain default emission factors and component counts for different equipment and regions, which can be used to calculate emissions from flares at gas processing facilities or well pads. However, the specific reporting requirements for emissions from all flares, including emergency flares, are not explicitly mentioned in the given input.
